elements.content: The synthesis of single-crystalline zinc glutarate (sc-ZnGA) by the hydrothermal reactions of zinc perchlorate hexahydrate and glutaronitrile and determining of its structure are first reported. sc-ZnGA presents a three-dimensional network framework constituted by the alternate arrangement of 16- and 24-membered metallacycle channels, which consist of ZnO4 layers interleaved with bent and fully extended glutarate ligands, respectively.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis of single-crystalline zinc glutarate (sc-ZnGA) by the hydrothermal reactions of zinc perchlorate hexahydrate and glutaronitrile and determining of its structure are first reported. sc-ZnGA presents a three-dimensional network framework constituted by the alternate arrangement of 16- and 24-membered metallacycle channels, which consist of ZnO4 layers interleaved with bent and fully extended glutarate ligands, respectively.

elements.content: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is currently regarded not only as a major greenhouse gas causing global warming but also as the cheapest and most abundant raw material source of carbon. The polymerization of CO2 with alkylene oxide to produce poly(alkylene carbonate) (PAC), a biocompatible material that undergoes complete thermal decomposition, has come to be widely regarded as one of the most effective methods for utilizing CO2. Considerable effort has been expended on developing organometallic catalysts with high catalytic performance for this CO2 polymerization process. Of the catalysts reported to date, zinc dicarboxylates are among the most effective for preparing PAC with a reasonably high molecular weight, and among the zinc dicarboxylates, zinc glutarate (ZnGA) gives the highest yield in the polymerization of CO2 with propylene oxide (PO). ZnGA is currently considered the most effective and economically viable catalyst for the large-scale conversion of CO2 resources into PAC materials. However, to date no structural information has been reported for this catalyst, and such information is essential if we are to understand its catalytic mechanism and activity. This lack of structural information is due in part to the difficulty of preparing single crystals of ZnGA, which results from its extremely low solubility in all common solvents [with the exception of strong acidic solutions (pH < 2), in which it dissociates]. Here, we present the first report of the synthesis of single-crystalline ZnGA and of the determination of its structure.
elements.clean_text: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is currently regarded not only as a major greenhouse gas causing global warming but also as the cheapest and most abundant raw material source of carbon. The polymerization of CO2 with alkylene oxide to produce poly(alkylene carbonate) (PAC), a biocompatible material that undergoes complete thermal decomposition, has come to be widely regarded as one of the most effective methods for utilizing CO2. Considerable effort has been expended on developing organometallic catalysts with high catalytic performance for this CO2 polymerization process. Of the catalysts reported to date, zinc dicarboxylates are among the most effective for preparing PAC with a reasonably high molecular weight, and among the zinc dicarboxylates, zinc glutarate (ZnGA) gives the highest yield in the polymerization of CO2 with propylene oxide (PO). ZnGA is currently considered the most effective and economically viable catalyst for the large-scale conversion of CO2 resources into PAC materials. However, to date no structural information has been reported for this catalyst, and such information is essential if we are to understand its catalytic mechanism and activity. This lack of structural information is due in part to the difficulty of preparing single crystals of ZnGA, which results from its extremely low solubility in all common solvents [with the exception of strong acidic solutions (pH < 2), in which it dissociates]. Here, we present the first report of the synthesis of single-crystalline ZnGA and of the determination of its structure.

elements.content: Single-crystalline ZnGA (sc-ZnGA) was first successfully synthesized with an average size of 1 mm × 1 mm × 10 μm (see the inset of Figure ) by the hydrothermal reaction of zinc perchlorate hexahydrate [Zn(ClO4)2·6H2O] and glutaronitrile [NC(CH2)3CN] at 160 °C, as shown in the following: This hydrothermal synthesis approach only gave sc-ZnGA when the zinc metal ion and glutarate ligand sources were zinc perchlorate hexahydrate and glutaronitrile, respectively. However, attempts to produce sc-ZnGA by hydrothermal reaction of glutaronitrile with other zinc ion sources (e.g., zinc chloride, zinc oxide, zinc nitrate, and zinc acetate) failed. Attempts to synthesize sc-ZnGA by hydrothermal reaction of glutaric acid with all the zinc ion sources including zinc perchlorate hexahydrate also failed.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystalline ZnGA (sc-ZnGA) was first successfully synthesized with an average size of 1 mm × 1 mm × 10 μm (see the inset of Figure ) by the hydrothermal reaction of zinc perchlorate hexahydrate [Zn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O] and glutaronitrile [NC(CH2)3CN] at 160 °C, as shown in the following:     This hydrothermal synthesis approach only gave sc-ZnGA when the zinc metal ion and glutarate ligand sources were zinc perchlorate hexahydrate and glutaronitrile, respectively. However, attempts to produce sc-ZnGA by hydrothermal reaction of glutaronitrile with other zinc ion sources (e.g., zinc chloride, zinc oxide, zinc nitrate, and zinc acetate) failed. Attempts to synthesize sc-ZnGA by hydrothermal reaction of glutaric acid with all the zinc ion sources including zinc perchlorate hexahydrate also failed.

elements.content: (a) Coordination geometry around the ZnII centers in sc-ZnGA. The atoms are distinguished as the following:  Zn, violet; O, red; C, gray. Selected bond distances (Å):  Zn(1)···Zn(2), 4.639; Zn(1)···Zn(3), 4.784; Zn(1)···O(1), 1.968; Zn(1)···O(2), 1.961; Zn(1)···O(3), 1.954; Zn(1)···O(4), 1.961. (b) View down the crystallographic c-axis. Inset:  Optical microscopy of sc-ZnGA; the crystallographic a-axis is parallel to the thickness direction of the single-crystal plate.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination geometry around the ZnII centers in sc-ZnGA. The atoms are distinguished as the following: Zn, violet; O, red; C, gray. Selected bond distances (Å): Zn(1)⋅⋅⋅Zn(2), 4.639; Zn(1)⋅⋅⋅Zn(3), 4.784; Zn(1)⋅⋅⋅O(1), 1.968; Zn(1)⋅⋅⋅O(2), 1.961; Zn(1)⋅⋅⋅O(3), 1.954; Zn(1)⋅⋅⋅O(4), 1.961. (b) View down the crystallographic c-axis. Inset: Optical microscopy of sc-ZnGA; the crystallographic a-axis is parallel to the thickness direction of the single-crystal plate.

elements.content: The infrared spectrum of sc-ZnGA resembles that of the powdery ZnGA commonly prepared from zinc oxide and glutaric acid. In particular, the spectrum exhibits a doublet band with peaks at 1585 and 1539 cm-1 due to the antisymmetric CO stretching vibration and a singlet band at 1405 cm-1 due to the symmetric CO stretching vibration, which indicates that glutarate ligands with two carboxyl end groups were successfully produced by the hydrolysis of glutaronitrile. Furthermore, the wavenumber differences of the antisymmetric bands with respect to the symmetric band are 180 and 134 cm-1, respectively, suggesting that the carboxyl end groups of the glutarate ligand are in bridging coordination with the zinc metal ion, as reported previously. The chemical formula of sc-ZnGA was confirmed by elemental analysis. The synthesis of sc-ZnGA was found to be highly reproducible. Evidence of the stability of sc-ZnGA was obtained by thermogravimetric analysis, which showed that sc-ZnGA begins to decompose at 471 °C.
elements.clean_text: The infrared spectrum of sc-ZnGA resembles that of the powdery ZnGA commonly prepared from zinc oxide and glutaric acid. In particular, the spectrum exhibits a doublet band with peaks at 1585 and 1539 cm-1 due to the antisymmetric CO stretching vibration and a singlet band at 1405 cm-1 due to the symmetric CO stretching vibration, which indicates that glutarate ligands with two carboxyl end groups were successfully produced by the hydrolysis of glutaronitrile. Furthermore, the wavenumber differences of the antisymmetric bands with respect to the symmetric band are 180 and 134 cm-1, respectively, suggesting that the carboxyl end groups of the glutarate ligand are in bridging coordination with the zinc metal ion, as reported previously. The chemical formula of sc-ZnGA was confirmed by elemental analysis. The synthesis of sc-ZnGA was found to be highly reproducible. Evidence of the stability of sc-ZnGA was obtained by thermogravimetric analysis, which showed that sc-ZnGA begins to decompose at 471 °C.

elements.content: X-ray single-crystal structure determinations16 revealed that the unit cell of sc-ZnGA is monoclinic with a P2/c space group and lattice parameters of a = 13.934(3) Å, b = 4.7842(11) Å, c = 9.276(2) Å, and β = 90.628(5)°, and its ZnII centers have a coordination of four. Each ZnII center coordinates to four different carboxyl oxygen atoms via η1,η‘1−bridging; for example, Zn(1) coordinates to four oxygen atoms, O(1), O(2), O(3), and O(4). All ZnII centers of sc-ZnGA thus coordinate to four carboxyl oxygen atoms on different glutarate ligands via four syn−anti bridges, forming a distorted tetrahedral geometry (see Figure a). This coordination pattern is very different from the structures commonly reported for zinc monocarboxylates, in which two zinc atoms are linked by three syn−syn and one syn−anti bridging carboxylate ligands to produce a linear(3,1) polymer.
elements.clean_text: X-ray single-crystal structure determinations16 revealed that the unit cell of sc-ZnGA is monoclinic with a P2/c space group and lattice parameters of a = 13.934(3) Å, b = 4.7842(11) Å, c = 9.276(2) Å, and β = 90.628(5)°, and its ZnII centers have a coordination of four. Each ZnII center coordinates to four different carboxyl oxygen atoms via η1,η‘1-bridging; for example, Zn(1) coordinates to four oxygen atoms, O(1), O(2), O(3), and O(4). All ZnII centers of sc-ZnGA thus coordinate to four carboxyl oxygen atoms on different glutarate ligands via four syn-anti bridges, forming a distorted tetrahedral geometry (see Figure a). This coordination pattern is very different from the structures commonly reported for zinc monocarboxylates, in which two zinc atoms are linked by three syn-syn and one syn-anti bridging carboxylate ligands to produce a linear(3,1) polymer.

elements.content: In the crystal structure of sc-ZnGA, the glutarate ligands take on either a bent (type-I) or a fully extended (type-II) conformation, depending on their location in the crystal structure. Type-I glutarate ligands coordinate to two ZnII ions on the c-axis [e.g., see the type-I ligand linked to Zn(1) and Zn(2) separated by an interatomic distance of 4.639 Å on the c-axis in Figure a]; the bent direction of the ligand alternately crosses along to the c-axis, as shown in Figure b. In contrast, type-II glutarate ligands coordinate to two ZnII ions on the b-axis [e.g., see the type-II ligand linked to Zn(1) and Zn(3) separated by an interatomic distance of 4.784 Å on the b-axis in Figure a]. Consequently, each ZnII center in sc-ZnGA coordinates with two carboxyl oxygen atoms from type-I glutarate ligands and two from type-II glutarate ligands, generating a three-dimensional network.
elements.clean_text: In the crystal structure of sc-ZnGA, the glutarate ligands take on either a bent (type-I) or a fully extended (type-II) conformation, depending on their location in the crystal structure. Type-I glutarate ligands coordinate to two ZnII ions on the c-axis [e.g., see the type-I ligand linked to Zn(1) and Zn(2) separated by an interatomic distance of 4.639 Å on the c-axis in Figure a]; the bent direction of the ligand alternately crosses along to the c-axis, as shown in Figure b. In contrast, type-II glutarate ligands coordinate to two ZnII ions on the b-axis [e.g., see the type-II ligand linked to Zn(1) and Zn(3) separated by an interatomic distance of 4.784 Å on the b-axis in Figure a]. Consequently, each ZnII center in sc-ZnGA coordinates with two carboxyl oxygen atoms from type-I glutarate ligands and two from type-II glutarate ligands, generating a three-dimensional network.

elements.content: Figure a shows a view down the crystallographic a-axis (in fact, the crystallographic a-axis in the single-crystal plate of the inset of Figure is parallel to the thickness direction of the crystal plate), while Figures b and b display views down the crystallographic b- and c-axis, respectively. As seen in Figures and b, two types of metallacycles are formed, which are distinguished by the conformations (type-I and type-II) of the glutarate ligands coordinated to the ZnII ions. One type is a 16-membered metallacycle (A) composed of two ZnII ions [e.g., Zn(1) and Zn(4) with an interatomic distance of 6.990 Å] and two glutarate ligands in the type-I conformation. The other type is a 24-membered metallacycle (B) composed of four ZnII ions [e.g., Zn(1), Zn(2), Zn(5), and Zn(6)] and two glutarate ligands in the type-II conformation as well as two carboxyl groups on two glutarate ligands in the type-I conformation; in this case, the interatomic distance of O(5) and O(6) is 12.895 Å, which is the longest interatomic distance in the metallacycle.
elements.clean_text: Figure a shows a view down the crystallographic a-axis (in fact, the crystallographic a-axis in the single-crystal plate of the inset of Figure  is parallel to the thickness direction of the crystal plate), while Figures b and b display views down the crystallographic b- and c-axis, respectively. As seen in Figures  and b, two types of metallacycles are formed, which are distinguished by the conformations (type-I and type-II) of the glutarate ligands coordinated to the ZnII ions. One type is a 16-membered metallacycle (A) composed of two ZnII ions [e.g., Zn(1) and Zn(4) with an interatomic distance of 6.990 Å] and two glutarate ligands in the type-I conformation. The other type is a 24-membered metallacycle (B) composed of four ZnII ions [e.g., Zn(1), Zn(2), Zn(5), and Zn(6)] and two glutarate ligands in the type-II conformation as well as two carboxyl groups on two glutarate ligands in the type-I conformation; in this case, the interatomic distance of O(5) and O(6) is 12.895 Å, which is the longest interatomic distance in the metallacycle.

elements.content: Three-dimensional molecular network structure insc-ZnGA. (a) View down the crystallographic a-axis. (b) View down the crystallographic b-axis showing the packing order of two types of metallacycles resulting from the coordinations of the glutarate ligands in the bent and fully extended conformations to ZnII ions:  A, 16-membered metallacycle; B, 24-membered metallacycle.
elements.clean_text: 2  Three-dimensional molecular network structure insc-ZnGA. (a) View down the crystallographic a-axis. (b) View down the crystallographic b-axis showing the packing order of two types of metallacycles resulting from the coordinations of the glutarate ligands in the bent and fully extended conformations to ZnII ions: A, 16-membered metallacycle; B, 24-membered metallacycle.

elements.content: Metallacycles A and B are arranged in alternating layers along the a-axis (mean separation = 6.968 Å) and make eclipsed stacks along the b-axis, forming their own channel structures (Figure b). In the case of metallacycle B channel, a small fraction of free volume is generated when the van der Waals radii of the constituent atoms are accounted for. The distance between ZnO4 layers in the metallacycle A channel is similar to that in the metallacycle B channel, but channel A is almost completely filled by the van der Waals radii of the constituent atoms due to the alkylenyl units of the ligands in the bent conformation. Due to these limited spaces, the carbon dioxide and alkylene oxide monomers cannot diffuse through the channels; however, the channels do give rise to a surface topology on which the monomers adsorb favorably.
elements.clean_text: Metallacycles A and B are arranged in alternating layers along the a-axis (mean separation = 6.968 Å) and make eclipsed stacks along the b-axis, forming their own channel structures (Figure b). In the case of  metallacycle B channel, a small fraction of free volume is generated when the van der Waals radii of the constituent atoms are accounted for. The distance between ZnO4 layers in the metallacycle A channel is similar to that in the metallacycle B channel, but channel A is almost completely filled by the van der Waals radii of the constituent atoms due to the alkylenyl units of the ligands in the bent conformation. Due to these limited spaces, the carbon dioxide and alkylene oxide monomers cannot diffuse through the channels; however, the channels do give rise to a surface topology on which the monomers adsorb favorably.

elements.content: In a previous study of ZnGA catalysts prepared from a variety of zinc precursors, we found that the catalyst with the highest crystallinity gave the highest polymer yield in the polymerization of CO2. That finding indicates that the catalytic activity of ZnGA is primarily determined by its morphological characteristics, including the size and quality of its crystals. In addition, polycarbonate products obtained from the copolymerization of CO2 and PO in the presence of a zinc carboxylate catalyst were found to be terminated with a carboxylate group originating from the catalyst. Moreover, in a recent near-edge X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy study of polycrystalline ZnGA catalyst, we found that the ZnGA catalyst reversibly reacts with CO2 and readily reacts with PO via adsorption onto the catalyst surface and insertion into the Zn−O bond. These results collectively suggest that the ZnII centers positioned at the surface function as active sites in the copolymerization of CO2 and alkylene oxide.
elements.clean_text: In a previous study of ZnGA catalysts prepared from a variety of zinc precursors, we found that the catalyst with the highest crystallinity gave the highest polymer yield in the polymerization of CO2. That finding indicates that the catalytic activity of ZnGA is primarily determined by its morphological characteristics, including the size and quality of its crystals. In addition, polycarbonate products obtained from the copolymerization of CO2 and PO in the presence of a zinc carboxylate catalyst were found to be terminated with a carboxylate group originating from the catalyst. Moreover, in a recent near-edge X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy study of polycrystalline ZnGA catalyst, we found that the ZnGA catalyst reversibly reacts with CO2 and readily reacts with PO via adsorption onto the catalyst surface and insertion into the Zn-O bond. These results collectively suggest that the ZnII centers positioned at the surface function as active sites in the copolymerization of CO2 and alkylene oxide.

elements.content: The present results show that the crystal structure of ZnGA features two distinct metallacycle channel structures that alternate along the a-axis, providing a thermally stable framework. The structural information obtained in the present study is crucial to understanding of the catalytic active sites of ZnGA that facilitate the copolymerization of CO2 and alkylene oxide. This understanding of the link between structure and catalytic activity can be used to guide the design of more effective catalysts.
elements.clean_text: The present results show that the crystal structure of ZnGA features two distinct metallacycle channel structures that alternate along the a-axis, providing a thermally stable framework. The structural information obtained in the present study is crucial to understanding of the catalytic active sites of ZnGA that facilitate the copolymerization of CO2 and alkylene oxide. This understanding of the link between structure and catalytic activity can be used to guide the design of more effective catalysts.

metadata.title:
Hydrothermal Synthesis of
Single-Crystalline Zinc Glutarate and Its
Structural Determination
